text: The Honorable Bernard Sanders
label: BODY

text: Chairman, Subcommittee on Primary Health and Aging
label: BODY

text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions
label: BODY

text: 648 Dirksen Senate Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC 20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders:
label: BODY

text: On behalf of the National Council on Aging, I am pleased to share NCOA's endorsement of the Older Americans
label: BODY

text: Act Amendments of 2013 and commend you for this important first step to spur a bipartisan, bicameral
label: BODY

text: reauthorization process for the 113th Congress.
label: BODY

text: We appreciate your continued leadership to advance a very thoughtful reauthorization package that continues
label: BODY

text: to recognize that the Act still provides a strong foundation for the Aging Services Network and its partners to
label: BODY

text: empower older adults to retain or improve their health and economic independence so they can remain in
label: BODY

text: their own homes and communities. The most significant reason why the Act has not yet fully realized its true
label: BODY

text: potential has been a lack of investment, which your bill addresses through several Sense of the Senate
label: BODY

text: statements.
label: BODY

text: Reauthorization of the OAA as increasing waves of Baby Boomers turn 65 is crucial to ensure that successes
label: BODY

text: of the Act can be better leveraged, and innovation continues to be fostered to meet the needs of today's
label: BODY

text: seniors. Proposals in your legislation that seize this opportunity include those which define economic security
label: BODY

text: and significantly establish it as a goal of the Act, emphasize the delivery of evidence-based chronic disease
label: BODY

text: self-management and falls prevention, promote senior center modernization, enhance the  Senior Community
label: BODY

text: Services Employment Program (SCSEP), and strengthen legal assistance and other elder justice provisions.
label: BODY

text: Together, these improvements can empower seniors and improve their health and economic security, bend
label: BODY

text: downward the long-term entitlements cost curve, and promote greater program efficiency and coordination.
label: BODY

text: We applaud your ongoing efforts to move OAA reauthorization forward, and we look forward to continuing to
label: BODY

text: work with you to promote a bipartisan process that remains true to the history of this important legislation.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: James P. Firman, Ed.D.
label: BODY

text: President & CEO
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernard Sanders
label: BODY

text: United States Senate
label: BODY

text: 332 Dirksen Senate Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, D.C. 20515
label: BODY

text: Dear Senator Sanders,
label: BODY

text: The Strengthen Social Security Coalition is comprised of over 350 national and statewide organizations,
label: BODY

text: including labor, womens, aging, disability, veterans and civil rights groups, whose goal is to strengthen
label: BODY

text: Social Security benefits for current and future beneficiaries. We are writing to express our unwavering
label: BODY

text: support for the reauthorization of the Older Americans Act. This vital piece of legislation has created
label: BODY

text: outlets of support for seniors to live in their communities with independence and dignity since 1965
label: BODY

text: when it was signed into law.
label: BODY

text: The Older Americans Act reauthorization directs the Bureau of Labor Statistics to create a more robust
label: BODY

text: version of the Consumer Price Index for the elderly (CPI-E) which is a more accurate measure of costs for
label: BODY

text: seniors. As compared to the rest of the population, the average senior disproportionately spends a
label: BODY

text: substantially larger portion of their income on health care, heating, cooling and other housing costs.
label: BODY

text: Adjusting the Cost of Living Adjustment (COLA) to reflect inflation based on the CPI-E would afford a
label: BODY

text: more accurate Social Security benefit for thousands of seniors across America who currently only
label: BODY

text: receive a modest income.
label: BODY

text: This reauthorization would strengthen the Older Americans Act by reauthorizing all programs through FY
label: BODY

text: 2018 and requesting a 12 percent increase in appropriations from FY 2010 in order to address the needs
label: BODY

text: of the baby boom generation. Updating the definitions of social and economic need to include outreach
label: BODY

text: to LGBT individuals, veterans, and those with Alzheimer’s disease is essential to providing quality
label: BODY

text: assistance to a diverse and growing senior population. The reauthorization also introduces efforts to
label: BODY

text: protect seniors from abuse and authorizes new grants to strengthen the environment of senior and
label: BODY

text: caregiver supports around the country- including the creation of the National Resource Center on Family
label: BODY

text: Caregiving.
label: BODY

text: The reauthorization of the Older Americans Act is critical to ensuring the wellbeing of seniors in the
label: BODY

text: United States who are committed to living out their days in the comfort of their own communities. Your
label: BODY

text: efforts to stand up as a voice for the aging population are celebrated among our coalition, and we thank
label: BODY

text: you for your strong leadership.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Nancy Altman
label: BODY

text: Eric Kingson
label: BODY

text: Coalition Co‐Chair
label: BODY

text: Coalition Co‐Chair
label: BODY

text: National Association of Nutrition and Aging Services Programs

label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders:
label: BODY

text: The National Association of Nutrition and Aging Services Programs (NANASP) is pleased to
label: BODY

text: support S.___, the Older Americans Act (OAA) Amendments of 2013.   Reauthorization of the
label: BODY

text: OAA is vital to the health, well-being and independence of millions of seniors across the
label: BODY

text: country.
label: BODY

text: NANASP is a 1,100-member national nonpartisan, nonprofit, membership organization for
label: BODY

text: persons across the country working to provide older adults healthful food and nutrition through
label: BODY

text: community-based services. Its members, as individuals, agencies and organizations, represent a
label: BODY

text: diverse coalition of those interested in senior nutrition programs. We strongly believe in these
label: BODY

text: programs and thank you for your support of them in the bill.
label: BODY

text: We feel that this bill is an excellent beginning to the work of reauthorizing the Older Americans
label: BODY

text: Act and we look forward to continuing to work with you and the Subcommittee throughout the
label: BODY

text: process. We appreciate your strong leadership and your dedication to seniors.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Paul Downey
label: BODY

text: Robert B. Blancato
label: BODY

text: President
label: HH1

text: Executive Director
label: HH1

text: Dear Chairman Sanders:
label: BODY

text: LeadingAge wants to thank you for your leadership in the process of re-authorizing the Older
label: BODY

text: Americans Act (OAA).  “The OAA Amendments of 2013” will be a major catalyst towards the
label: BODY

text: passage of a Re-authorized Older Americans Act that will better serve older adults in our
label: BODY

text: communities.
label: BODY

text: LeadingAge members and affiliates touch the lives of 4 million individuals, families, employees
label: BODY

text: and volunteers every day. The LeadingAge community (www.LeadingAge.org) includes 6,000
label: BODY

text: not-for-profit organizations in the United States, 39 state partners, hundreds of businesses,
label: BODY

text: research partners, consumer organizations, foundations and a broad global network of aging
label: BODY

text: services organizations that reach over 30 countries.  The work of LeadingAge is focused on
label: BODY

text: advocacy, education, and applied research. We promote adult day services, home health, hospice,
label: BODY

text: community-based services, PACE, senior housing, assisted living residences, continuing care
label: BODY

text: communities, nursing homes as well as technology solutions and person-centered practices that
label: BODY

text: support the overall health and wellbeing of seniors, children, and those with special needs.
label: BODY

text: This important legislation increases the focus on preventing elder abuse. It provides $5 million in
label: BODY

text: funding for the Community Innovations for Aging in Place. This program over the years
label: BODY

text: improved the collaboration between affordable senior housing and long-term services and
label: BODY

text: supports through Naturally Occurring Retirement Communities. LeadingAge is also pleased to
label: BODY

text: see that the bill helps Area Agencies on Aging and Aging and Disability Resource Centers
label: BODY

text: continue to work closely with long-term services and support providers to improve care
label: BODY

text: transitions for frail older adults.
label: BODY

text: We applaud you for your commitment to older Americans, and we look forward to working with
label: BODY

text: you throughout this reauthorization process.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: William L. Minnix, Jr.
label: BODY

text: President and CEO
label: BODY

text: National Association of State Long-Term Care Ombudsman Programs
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernard Sanders, Chairman
label: BODY

text: Senate Subcommittee on Primary Health and Aging

text: United States Senate

text: 648 Dirksen Senate Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, D.C. 20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Senator Sanders:
label: BODY

text: The National Association of State Long-Term Care Ombudsman Programs (NASOP) is pleased to
label: BODY

text: support your legislation, the Older Americans Act Amendments of 2013, which, among other things,
label: BODY

text: would improve the capacity of State Long-Term Care Ombudsman Programs to advocate for residents
label: BODY

text: of long-term care facilities.
label: BODY

text: As you are well aware, the Long-Term Care Ombudsman Program (LTCOP) identifies, investigates and
label: BODY

text: resolves complaints made by or on behalf of residents of long-term care facilities that affect their health,
label: BODY

text: safety, welfare, or rights.  Clarifying that residents have regular, timely, private and unimpeded access to
label: BODY

text: LTCOP services strengthens residents’ rights to assistance from our Program.  Improving the ability of
label: BODY

text: the LTCOP to access all records pertaining to residents and clarifying that the LTCOP is a Health
label: BODY

text: Oversight Agency improves the LTCOP’s ability to investigate and resolve resident complaints.
label: BODY

text: Removing organizational conflicts of interest and clarifying the relationship between the State Long-
label: BODY

text: Term Care Ombudsman and designated local entities ensures the independence of the LTCOP and
label: BODY

text: strengthens the unity of statewide LTCOPs under the leadership of the State Long-Term Care
label: BODY

text: Ombudsman.  Restoring maintenance of effort provisions that protect federal and state funding for the
label: BODY

text: Program and increasing funding in Title VII will protect our ability to ensure regular and timely access to
label: BODY

text: Ombudsman services.  Authorizing Title IIIE National Family Caregiver Program funding to support the
label: BODY

text: work of the LTCOP in helping establish and assist family councils in long-term care facilities, identifies
label: BODY

text: an unmet need to support family caregivers who continue to care for loved ones.
label: BODY

text: We applaud your vision and efforts to improve the whole Act and especially your attention to the often-
label: BODY

text: neglected long-term care system.  NASOP enthusiastically supports your efforts and this important
label: BODY

text: legislation that protects the rights of all residents of long-term care facilities.  We look forward to working
label: BODY

text: with you as the OAA reauthorization process moves ahead.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Joseph Rodrigues
label: BODY

text: President
label: HH1

text: William Lamb, President
label: BODY

text: Sarah F. Wells, Executive Director
label: BODY

text: www.theconsumervoice.org
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernie Sanders
label: BODY

text: United States Senate
label: BODY

text: 332 Dirksen Senate Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC 20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Senator Sanders,
label: BODY

text: The National Consumer Voice for Quality Long-Term Care (Consumer Voice) commends you for
label: BODY

text: the introduction of the Older Americans Act Amendments of 2013. We support this critical
label: BODY

text: legislation, which is a much-needed first step towards reauthorizing essential Older Americans Act
label: BODY

text: programs, and are particularly pleased that it includes provisions to protect the rights and well-
label: BODY

text: being of elders living in long-term care facilities, as well as those at home and in the community.
label: BODY

text: As you are aware, residents of long-term care facilities need effective advocacy in order to ensure
label: BODY

text: that they receive the quality of care and quality of life they deserve and are entitled to by law. The
label: BODY

text: purpose of the Long-Term Care Ombudsman Program is to provide residents with access to such
label: BODY

text: advocacy. The Older Americans Act Amendments of 2013 would strengthen and improve this
label: BODY

text: program’s effectiveness in a number of important ways. This legislation would clarify both
label: BODY

text: organizational and individual conflicts of interest within the program; clarify that the State
label: BODY

text: Ombudsman is responsible for the management of the Office of the State Long-Term Care
label: BODY

text: Ombudsman, including the office’s fiscal management; improve resident access to ombudsmen;
label: BODY

text: and ensure that State Ombudsmen receive ongoing training. It would also enhance the ability of
label: BODY

text: the National Ombudsman Resource Center to train and support both state and local ombudsmen by
label: BODY

text: increasing the Center’s funding.
label: BODY

text: Furthermore, older adults receiving services and supports at home also deserve similar protections
label: BODY

text: to ensure they are receiving high-quality care and a good quality of life. Yet these individuals have
label: BODY

text: few, if any, rights and protections under current law. The Older Americans Act Amendments of
label: BODY

text: 2013 would guarantee home care consumers basic rights, including the right to safety, as well as
label: BODY

text: information about costs, choice, and redress of grievances. The legislation would also advance the
label: BODY

text: development of ombudsman advocacy for home care consumers, who are frequently just as frail
label: BODY

text: and vulnerable as nursing home residents.
label: BODY

text: The Consumer Voice thanks you and your staff for the hard work and dedication that led to the
label: BODY

text: introduction of the Older Americans Act Amendments of 2013. We look forward to continuing to
label: BODY

text: work with your office in support of this vital bill during the coming months.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Sarah Wells
label: BODY

text: Robyn Grant
label: BODY

text: Executive Director
label: HH1

text: Director of Public Policy & Advocacy
label: BODY

text: The National Consumer Voice for Quality Long-Term Care (formerly NCCNHR) is a 501(c) (3) nonprofit membership
label: BODY

text: organization founded in 1975 by Elma L. Holder that advocates for quality care and quality of life for consumers in all
label: BODY

text: long-term-care settings.
label: BODY

text: 1001 Connecticut Avenue, NW • Suite 425 • Washington, DC 20036
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernie Sanders
label: BODY

text: 332 Dirksen Senate Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC 20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Senator Sanders:
label: BODY

text: The National Hispanic Council on Aging (NHCOA) – the leading national organization working to
label: BODY

text: improve the lives of Hispanic older adults, their families, and caregivers – is proud to endorse the
label: BODY

text: Older Americans Act (OAA) Amendments of 2013.  We applaud you for your efforts to strengthen
label: BODY

text: the services and supports of the OAA and help make them available to all older adults.  Hispanic
label: BODY

text: seniors often struggle to access services that are available in their communities, but it is NHCOA’s
label: BODY

text: hope that your amendments will help them get the assistance they need to live independently and in
label: BODY

text: the best possible health.
label: BODY

text: The population of older adults in the United States is growing quickly, and the OAA needs to reflect
label: BODY

text: this changing demographic.  NHCOA strongly supports the increased funding requested for the
label: BODY

text: vitally important meals, transportation, caregiver support, and employment training that the OAA
label: BODY

text: provides.  For many years, parts of the OAA have gone without funding increases.  The increased
label: BODY

text: funding of the OAA Amendments of 2013 will allow service providers to meet the increased demand
label: BODY

text: created by the growing population of older adults.
label: BODY

text: NHCOA is also happy that the OAA Amendments of 2013 place a priority on the delivery of services
label: BODY

text: and supports in a culturally and linguistically appropriate manner.  In addition to growing larger, the
label: BODY

text: population of older adults in the U.S. is also become more diverse.  Currently, cultural and linguistic
label: BODY

text: barriers make it difficult for Hispanic older adults to access available services.  The OAA
label: BODY

text: Amendments of 2013 help break down those barriers.  Prioritizing services that meet the unique
label: BODY

text: cultural and linguistic needs of older adults is a tremendous step forward for the OAA.
label: BODY

text: Thank you for leadership and for your support of older adults.  NHCOA looks forward to working
label: BODY

text: with you to further improve the lives of Hispanic older adults, their families, and caregivers.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Yanira Cruz, Dr.PH
label: BODY

text: President & CEO
label: BODY

text: 1140 19th Street, NW ∙ Suite 550 ∙ Washington, DC ∙ 20036 ∙ wiserwomen.org
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernard Sanders
label: BODY

text: Chairman, Subcommittee on Primary Health and Aging
label: BODY

text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions
label: BODY

text: U.S. Senate, 648 Dirksen Senate Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC  20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders:
label: BODY

text: It is with great pleasure that I write in support of the Older Americans Act Reauthorization legislation that
label: BODY

text: you are introducing this week.  Please add the Women's Institute for a Secure Retirement (WISER) to your
label: BODY

text: list of supporters.  I truly appreciate all of your efforts to strengthen and expand the programs under the
label: BODY

text: OAA in both this Congress and in the 112th Congress.
label: BODY

text: The importance of the Older Americans Act to millions of older adults should not be underestimated.  The
label: BODY

text: impact and influence of the OAA is felt far and wide but intimately, too, in the meals that seniors eat every
label: BODY

text: day, and in the protections and assistance that individuals receive from the many and varied programs and
label: BODY

text: services.
label: BODY

text: The programs of WISER and the National Education and Resource Center on Women and Retirement
label: BODY

text: Planning are great examples of OAA programs that reach older adults in one of the most important ways
label: BODY

text: possible: by protecting women from financial exploitation and poverty in their older years.  As you know,
label: BODY

text: the center, administered by WISER, plays a critical role in addressing financial literacy and predatory
label: BODY

text: practices.  Predatory practices cost Americans $25 billion annually, robbing women, particularly elderly
label: BODY

text: women, of precious assets and putting their home ownership at risk.  The face of the victim is often a “cash
label: BODY

text: poor, house rich” elderly widow, often African American, less-educated, and vulnerable.  These are the
label: BODY

text: individuals that make up WISER’s audience and the people to whom WISER focuses its outreach.
label: BODY

text: Being a target when you are at this vulnerable stage of your life has extreme consequences – being
label: BODY

text: swindled out of your life savings is not only devastating but also life threatening. Older women are targeted
label: BODY

text: not only by strangers who are con artists, unscrupulous salespeople, contractors or others, but by those who
label: BODY

text: are known to them and who have power over them such as family caregivers or someone with a power of
label: BODY

text: attorney or other fiduciary obligation.  WISER has partnered with the National Adult Protective Services
label: BODY

text: Association to develop education materials, training programs, and outreach to educate, recognize, and
label: BODY

text: prevent elder financial exploitation.
label: BODY

text: In closing, let me again thank you for introducing this important piece of legislation that supports some of
label: BODY

text: the most effective and essential programs that we offer older Americans.  Please let me know how I may be
label: BODY

text: of assistance during the upcoming legislative process.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Cindy Hounsell
label: BODY

text: President
label: HH1

text: The Honorable Bernard Sanders
label: BODY

text: United States Senate
label: BODY

text: 332 Dirksen Senate Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, D.C. 20515
label: BODY

text: Dear Senator Sanders,
label: BODY

text: We are delighted to express our firm support for the reauthorization of the Older Americans Act. We are
label: BODY

text: particularly pleased with the CPI-E provision, as discussed below. Since 1965, this Act has helped millions
label: BODY

text: of seniors live with independence and dignity within their own homes and communities. The Older
label: BODY

text: Americans Act created the primary organizing tool, the Administration on Aging, statewide Area
label: BODY

text: Agencies on Aging, as well as programs like Meals on Wheels, and various volunteer services. These
label: BODY

text: programs have allowed thousands of older adults the flexibility and autonomy in deciding the type of
label: BODY

text: environment they would like to live in during their later years.
label: BODY

text: This reauthorization addresses the shortfalls of seniors’ current economic security by directing the
label: BODY

text: Bureau of Labor Statistics to create a more robust version of the Consumer Price Index for the Elderly
label: BODY

text: (CPI-E) within a 2 year window. Current benefits are very modest. The current CPI does not adequately
label: BODY

text: reflect seniors’ disproportionally large housing and health care expenditures relative to other age
label: BODY

text: groups. As a consequence, benefits erode over time. This CPI-E would create a more accurate measure
label: BODY

text: of the true cost of living seniors experience, which would help alleviate some financial strain as they age.
label: BODY

text: The Older Americans Act reauthorization is vital to ensuring the wellbeing of the growing senior
label: BODY

text: population in the United States. The coordinated systems of services enacted by this reauthorization
label: BODY

text: would revitalize an essential piece of legislation in order to accommodate the needs of the growing
label: BODY

text: senior population.
label: BODY

text: We applaud your continued leadership on the Older Americans Act, and we are honored to endorse this
label: BODY

text: legislation.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Nancy Altman
label: BODY

text: Eric Kingson
label: BODY

text: Coalition Co-Chair
label: BODY

text: Coalition Co-Chair
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernard Sanders, Chairman
label: BODY

text: Subcommittee on Primary Health and Aging
label: BODY

text: Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee
label: BODY

text: United States Senate
label: BODY

text: 428 Senate Dirksen Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC 20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders:
label: BODY

text: The National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys wishes to express its support for your bill, the Older
label: BODY

text: Americans Act Amendments of 2013.  We thank you and your staff for the many hours that you have spent
label: BODY

text: listening to stakeholders from across the country, establishing goals for this reauthorization, and drafting
label: BODY

text: the bill that you plan to introduce this week.  This is an important step in what should be an open,
label: BODY

text: bipartisan, and bicameral process of reauthorizing this important law.
label: BODY

text: In particular, we believe that your continuing commitment to strengthen the quality of and access to legal
label: BODY

text: services for older adults is essential in this reauthorization.  In addition, your provisions that recognize
label: BODY

text: that the long-term care ombudsman program can be significantly improved by changes to the current law
label: BODY

text: that will not demand any additional resources are greatly appreciated.  Moreover, your bill adds important
label: BODY

text: language consistent with the Elder Justice Act that will promote the fight against elder abuse, neglect, and
label: BODY

text: exploitation on the federal, state, and local levels.
label: BODY

text: NAELA is a professional association consisting of more than 4,300 attorneys who advocate for the rights
label: BODY

text: of seniors and people with disabilities.  Elder law attorneys are specialized and trained in a variety of
label: BODY

text: areas in the law that address an individual’s long-term care needs.  We thank you for including our
label: BODY

text: perspectives in the process and your steadfast commitment to providing much needed services to older
label: BODY

text: adults, particularly those in the greatest economic and social need.
label: BODY

text: Our members see clients every day who have benefited or could benefit from OAA programs, and we are
label: BODY

text: strong supporters of its reauthorization in the 113th Congress.  Please let us know what we can do to help
label: BODY

text: you in this effort.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Peter G. Wacht, CAE
label: BODY

text: Gregory S. French, CELA, CAP
label: BODY

text: Executive Director
label: HH1

text: President
label: HH1

text: The Jewish Federations of North America (JFNA) and the Association of Jewish
label: BODY

text: Family & Children’s Agencies (AJFCA) are pleased to endorse the Older Americans
label: BODY

text: Act reauthorization bill.  We urge Senators to support this legislation and reauthorize
label: BODY

text: the Older Americans Act with sufficient funding to meet the needs of seniors as soon as
label: BODY

text: possible.
label: BODY

text: JFNA represents 154 Jewish Federations & over 300 independent Jewish communities.
label: BODY

text: The Jewish Federations, collectively among the top 10 charities on the continent,
label: BODY

text: protects and enhances the well-being of Jews worldwide through the values of tikkun
label: BODY

text: olam (repairing the world), tzedakah (charity and social justice) and Torah (Jewish
label: BODY

text: learning).  AJFCA is the membership association for approximately 125 Jewish Family
label: BODY

text: Service agencies across the United States and Canada. Ranging in size from small
label: BODY

text: departments of local Jewish Federations to some of the largest human services agencies
label: BODY

text: in North America, our members provide vital services to clients of all ages, faiths and
label: BODY

text: economic backgrounds. They counsel families, feed the hungry, assist the elderly and
label: BODY

text: protect the vulnerable. We are united by the values of our Jewish tradition and work
label: BODY

text: together toward our common goal of tikkun olam, repairing the world.
label: BODY

text: Our network is comprised of experts in aging services for all seniors and we make up
label: BODY

text: the primary social service providers for Holocaust survivors in the United States.  As
label: BODY

text: people who work with Holocaust survivors in their homes and in the community, we
label: BODY

text: are reminded each day of the importance of enabling Holocaust survivors to remain
label: BODY

text: safely at home with their communities.  The negative effects of isolation can be
label: BODY

text: devastating for survivors who also face financial challenges and fewer family members
label: BODY

text: to help care for them.  The ability to help provide that comfort and quality of life will be
label: BODY

text: enhanced if the Responding to Urgent needs of Survivors of the Holocaust (RUSH) Act,
label: BODY

text: which is incorporated into this reauthorization bill, were to become law.
label: BODY

text: We also strongly support efforts to provide congregate and home-delivered meals that
label: BODY

text: are culturally appropriate based on religious or ethnic requirement or health-related
label: BODY

text: concerns; funding of Title IV to help develop and carry out innovative demonstration
label: BODY

text: projects that advance and sustain healthy, efficient, and independent community-based
label: BODY

text: aging; strengthening the National Family Caregiver Support program; and funding for
label: BODY

text: the Senior Community Service Employment Program; among other important
label: BODY

text: initiatives supported by the Older Americans Act.
label: BODY

text: JFNA and AJFCA look forward to cooperating with members of the Senate to move
label: BODY

text: reauthorization of the Older Americans Act forward.  For additional information, please
label: BODY

text: contact Shelley Rood at JFNA at shelley.rood@jewishfederations.org  or (202) 736-
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Association of Jewish Family & Children’s Agencies
label: BODY

text: The Jewish Federations of North America
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernie Sanders
label: BODY

text: Chairman, Subcommittee on Primary Health and Aging
label: BODY

text: Senate Health, Education, Labor & Pensions Committee
label: BODY

text: 322 Dirksen Senate Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC 20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders,
label: BODY

text: On behalf of the 158 Goodwill Industries agencies in the United States, I am writing in support of
label: BODY

text: proposed changes to Title V of the Older Americans Act contained in the Older Americans Act
label: BODY

text: Amendments Act of 2013.
label: BODY

text: The Older Americans Act (OAA) was the first federal-level legislation aimed at providing comprehensive
label: BODY

text: services for older adults.  Since its original passage in 1964, tens of millions of seniors have benefited
label: BODY

text: from the services provided by the OAA.    Among those services are the employment services provided
label: BODY

text: under Title V-Community Service Senior Opportunities Act, commonly referred to as the Senior
label: BODY

text: Community Service Employment Program (SCSEP).  SCSEP is a program administered by the United
label: BODY

text: States Department of Labor’s Employment and Training Administration that helps low-income people
label: BODY

text: who are 55 and older to return to or remain active in the workforce.   The recession that began in 2008
label: BODY

text: seriously hurt the standard of living for many seniors, moving many from middle-income to low-income
label: BODY

text: brackets. At a time when our fragile economy continues to struggle to recover from the recession, the
label: BODY

text: importance of the SCSEP program has never been greater.
label: BODY

text: The Older American Act Amendments of 2013 will require the Assistant Secretary for Aging and the
label: BODY

text: Secretary of Labor to conduct a feasibility study and submit a report to Congress on the proposed transfer
label: BODY

text: of the Senior Community Service Employment Program from the Department of Labor Employment and
label: BODY

text: Training Administration to the Health and Human Services Administration on Aging.  While Goodwill
label: BODY

text: supports keeping the SCSEP program located within the Department of Labor, it also supports the study
label: BODY

text: language that will be part of the proposed legislation. Goodwill believes such a study would provide
label: BODY

text: greater clarity on Title V’s interconnection with other Titles within OAA and provide Congress and the
label: BODY

text: Administration with more data on how significant SCSEP’s role is as a workforce development program
label: BODY

text: for our nation’s most at-risk seniors.
label: BODY

text: We appreciate your efforts on behalf of older Americans, especially in these difficult times.  Please feel
label: BODY

text: free to contact Paul Seifert, Senior Public Policy Specialist at paul.seifert@goodwill.org or at (240) 333-
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Jim Gibbons, President & CEO
label: BODY

text: Goodwill Industries International
label: BODY

text: The Eldercare Workforce Alliance is a project of The Advocacy Fund.
label: BODY

text: The positions of the Eldercare Workforce Alliance reflect a consensus of 75 percent or more of its members,
label: BODY

text: and do not necessarily represent the position of individual Alliance member organizations.
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernie Sanders, Chairman
label: BODY

text: Subcommittee on Primary Health & Aging
label: BODY

text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor & Pensions
label: BODY

text: U.S. Senate
label: BODY

text: 332 Dirksen Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, D.C.  20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders,
label: BODY

text: We are writing on behalf of the Eldercare Workforce Alliance (EWA), a coalition of 28 national
label: BODY

text: organizations—representing consumers, family caregivers, the direct‐care workforce, and health
label: BODY

text: care professionals—joined together to address the immediate and future workforce crisis in caring
label: BODY

text: for an aging America.  We applaud your efforts to move forward with reauthorization of the Older
label: BODY

text: Americans Act (OAA) in the 113th Congress.  OAA reauthorization offers an important opportunity
label: BODY

text: to help modernize the aging services network and its programs in order to build an eldercare
label: BODY

text: workforce with the skills and training to meet the “whole person” needs of older adults for health
label: BODY

text: care and long‐term services and supports (LTSS).
label: BODY

text: EWA supports the Older Americans Act Amendments of 2013, particularly its provisions to support
label: BODY

text: family caregivers and strengthen the eldercare workforce.  Provisions in your legislation which
label: BODY

text: contribute to these important goals include those that strengthen support for family caregivers
label: BODY

text: through grants to states to conduct assessments of family or informal caregiver needs, enhance the
label: BODY

text: work of Federal agencies to improve and develop new models for care coordination, test models
label: BODY

text: that provide direct‐care workers with additional training for new roles, and direct the
label: BODY

text: Administration on Aging to work with other federal agencies to identify and address eldercare
label: BODY

text: workforce shortages.
label: BODY

text: The Eldercare Workforce Alliance looks forward to continued engagement in the OAA
label: BODY

text: reauthorization process.  Our nation faces a severe and growing shortage of eldercare providers
label: BODY

text: with the skills and training to meet the unique health care needs of older adults.  The Alliance is
label: BODY

text: committed to supporting the reauthorization of the OAA as it invests in building and maintaining an
label: BODY

text: eldercare workforce that supports well‐coordinated, high‐quality care for older adults.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Nancy Lundebjerg, MPA
label: BODY

text: Michèle J. Saunders, DMD, MS, MPH
label: BODY

text: EWA Co‐Convener
label: BODY

text: EWA Co‐Convener
label: BODY

text: nlundebjerg@americangeriatrics.org
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 18th Floor

label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders:
label: BODY

text: The Elder Justice Coalition (EJC) is pleased to support The Older Americans Act Amendments
label: BODY

text: of 2013. We sincerely appreciate the efforts you and your staff have made to address the issue of
label: BODY

text: elder abuse, neglect and exploitation in your bill.
label: BODY

text: In particular, we want to congratulate you on adding victims of elder abuse to the category of
label: BODY

text: those who are in “greatest social need.” This is very important because older adults who have
label: BODY

text: been physically or financially abused or exploited are particularly vulnerable individuals in our
label: BODY

text: society and they deserve the highest level of protection we can afford them. In addition, your bill
label: BODY

text: helps to make consistent the approach and definitions used in the Elder Justice Act, and your bill
label: BODY

text: makes permanent the National Resource Center for Women and Retirement and the National
label: BODY

text: Adult Protective Services Resource Center. Further, your support for the State Home Care
label: BODY

text: Ombudsman Program as well as your support for the State Long-Term Care Ombudsman
label: BODY

text: Program is greatly appreciated.
label: BODY

text: We feel that this bill is an excellent beginning to the work of reauthorizing the Older Americans
label: BODY

text: Act and we look forward to continuing to work with you and the Subcommittee throughout the
label: BODY

text: process. We appreciate your strong leadership and your dedication to the prevention of elder
label: BODY

text: abuse and to the causes of older Americans.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Robert B. Blancato
label: BODY

text: National Coordinator
label: BODY

text: Elder Justice Coalition
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernie Sanders
label: BODY

text: Chair, Subcommittee on Primary Health and Aging
label: BODY

text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions
label: BODY

text: 428 Senate Dirksen Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC  20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Senator Sanders:
label: BODY

text: Thank you for your Older Americans Act reauthorization bill and its many improvements to help aging parents
label: BODY

text: caring for their adult children with disabilities.  The Developmental Disabilities, Autism and Family Support
label: BODY

text: Task Force of the Consortium for Citizens with Disabilities (CCD) greatly appreciates the proposed
label: BODY

text: amendments to the National Family Caregiver Support program (NFCSP) and the Aging and Disability
label: BODY

text: Resource Centers (ARDCs).
label: BODY

text: The NFCSP was the first federal program to recognize the needs of the nation’s family caregivers who provide
label: BODY

text: the vast majority of long-term services and supports. NFCSP not only funds respite, but individual counseling,
label: BODY

text: support groups, and caregiver training for family caregivers, primarily for those who are caring for the aging
label: BODY

text: population. Unfortunately, the NFCSP currently is only available to caregivers of persons age 60 and over.
label: BODY

text: Your bill would make the program available to the increasing number of Americans who need it by including
label: BODY

text: caregivers of their adult children (age 19 to 59) with disabilities.  This needed improvement would not come a
label: BODY

text: moment too soon.
label: BODY

text: There are over 730,000 caregivers of persons with intellectual and developmental disabilities who are over the
label: BODY

text: age of 60 and this number is projected to grow substantially with the aging of the baby boom generation.
label: BODY

text: People with intellectual and developmental disabilities are also living longer due to medical advances. As
label: BODY

text: parents of these individuals age, they will require more support to be able to continue providing care to their
label: BODY

text: adult children and avoiding costly and unwanted institutional placement.
label: BODY

text: The aging of the caregiver population is central to another welcome provision in the bill – the addition of
label: BODY

text: ADRCS assisting aging caregivers and adults with disabilities with future planning.  The lack of family future
label: BODY

text: planning often results in inappropriate residential placements, loss of intended inheritance, and jeopardizes
label: BODY

text: access to needed services for adults with disabilities as they age.  For instance, long waiting lists preclude
label: BODY

text: appropriate community-based residential options for many individuals with lifelong disabilities. Providing future
label: BODY

text: planning services will provide immense relief to aging caregivers who frequently report that they are “afraid to
label: BODY

text: die.”
label: BODY

text: More than at any other time, when Medicaid, Medicare, and Social Security are being severely threatened,
label: BODY

text: helping family caregivers to continue providing long-term services and supports is good public policy.  We look
label: BODY

text: forward to working with you on the reauthorization of the Older Americans Act that will improve services for our
label: BODY

text: nation’s caregivers.
label: BODY

text: 1825 K Street, NW, Suite 1200 • Washington, DC  20006 • PH 202-783-2229 • FAX 202-783-8250 • Info@c-c-d.org • www.c-c-d.org
label: BODY

text: CCD is a coalition of national disability organizations working together to advocate for national public policy
label: BODY

text: that ensures the self-determination, independence, empowerment, integration and inclusion of children and
label: BODY

text: adults with disabilities in all aspects of society.
label: BODY

text: For more information, please contact any of the following Task Force Co-Chairs:

label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders:
label: BODY

text: On behalf of the millions of members and supporters of the National Committee to Preserve Social Security
label: BODY

text: and Medicare, I am writing to thank you for introducing the Older Americans Act Amendments of 2011, which
label: BODY

text: reauthorizes the Older Americans Act (OAA). We share your hope that this legislation and other proposals to
label: BODY

text: strengthen the OAA will receive bipartisan support in Congress early in 2012. Older Americans Act programs
label: BODY

text: – such as in-home assistance, home-delivered and congregate meals, respite for family caregivers, preventive
label: BODY

text: health services, job training and placement, and legal services - benefit individuals and their families. By
label: BODY

text: helping seniors stay as independent as possible in their homes and communities, these programs also save
label: BODY

text: federal and state government resources from being spent on sometimes unnecessary and often much more
label: BODY

text: expensive care in hospitals and nursing homes. We understand that your legislation improves the OAA
label: BODY

text: programs. In addition, your bill acknowledges that there is simply not enough money allocated for OAA
label: BODY

text: programs to meet the needs of our growing elderly population.
label: BODY

text: The National Committee also applauds you for the provision in the Older Americans Act Amendments of 2011
label: BODY

text: which requires the Secretary of Labor to revise and improve the experimental price index for the elderly,
label: BODY

text: commonly referred to as the CPI-E, so that it can be considered as a replacement for the consumer price index
label: BODY

text: that is being used to adjust Social Security benefits for inflation. We believe that the CPI-E is based on a
label: BODY

text: market basket of goods that more accurately reflects the spending patterns of the elderly and thus is a better
label: BODY

text: index for  the purpose of protecting seniors from the harmful effects of inflation. Revising and improving the
label: BODY

text: experimental CPI-E is an essential first step in its adoption as the CPI of record for the Social Security
label: BODY

text: program.
label: BODY

text: Thank you for your leadership on the Older Americans Act reauthorization. We look forward to working with
label: BODY

text: you to strengthen these important programs that go a long way toward ensuring economic security and
label: BODY

text: independence for older Americans and their family caregivers.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Sherrie Dornberger
label: BODY

text: Sherrie Dornberger, RN, CDONA, CDP, GDCN, FACDONA
label: BODY

text: Executive Director NADONA/LTC
label: BODY

text: 11353 Reed Hartman Hwy., Suite 210
label: BODY

text: Cincinnati, OH. 45241
label: BODY

text: To: Sophie Kasimow, Staff Director, HELP Subcommittee on Primary Health & Aging
label: BODY

text: From: Lisa Pugh, Public Policy Coordinator, Wisconsin’s Disability Policy Partnership
label: BODY

text: Re: Older Americans Act reauthorization bill
label: BODY

text: I am writing to indicate our agency’s support for the Older Americans Act reauthorization
label: BODY

text: bill to be introduced by Senator Sanders. Our agency had previously worked with Senator
label: BODY

text: Kohl’s office on many of these important issues. This bill includes an important fix to the
label: BODY

text: National Family Caregiver Support Program to include older relative caregivers of adults
label: BODY

text: with disabilities. It also amends the core functions of ADRCs to include that they assist
label: BODY

text: aging caregivers and adults with disabilities with future planning.  The language on
label: BODY

text: caregiver assessments will also be extremely helpful for aging caregivers of adults with
label: BODY

text: disabilities.
label: BODY

text: Thank you for your work on this bill. We look forward to providing additional input and
label: BODY

text: supporting its passage.
label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders,
label: BODY

text: AMDA-Dedicated to Long Term Care Medicine applauds your efforts to move
label: BODY

text: forward with reauthorization of the Older Americans Act (OAA) in the 113th
label: BODY

text: Congress. AMDA is the professional association of nursing home medical directors,
label: BODY

text: nursing home attending physicians, and other professionals practicing in the post-
label: BODY

text: acute and long term care continuum. We work to ensure excellence in patient care
label: BODY

text: and to promote the delivery of quality post-acute and long term care medicine.
label: BODY

text: AMDA supports the Older Americans Act Amendments of 2013, particularly its
label: BODY

text: provisions to strengthen the eldercare workforce and continue funding the long term
label: BODY

text: care ombudsman program.  Provisions in your legislation which contribute to these
label: BODY

text: important goals include those that strengthen support for family and informal
label: BODY

text: caregivers through grants to states to conduct assessments of family or informal
label: BODY

text: caregiver needs, test new innovative models of person and family-centered care that
label: BODY

text: encourage well-coordinated, interdisciplinary team care, test models that provide
label: BODY

text: direct-care workers with additional training for new roles, and direct the
label: BODY

text: Administration on Aging to work with other federal agencies to identify and address
label: BODY

text: eldercare workforce shortages. Also included is support for the Long Term Care
label: BODY

text: Ombudsman Program, which addresses the many and varied problems facing long
label: BODY

text: term care residents. State Ombudsmen play an important role in protecting nursing
label: BODY

text: home residents, especially in promoting the development of citizen organizations and
label: BODY

text: family residence councils.
label: BODY

text: AMDA looks forward to continued engagement in the OAA reauthorization process.
label: BODY

text: Our nation faces a severe and growing shortage of eldercare providers with the skills
label: BODY

text: and training to meet the unique health care needs of older adults.   AMDA is
label: BODY

text: committed to supporting the reauthorization of the OAA as it invests in building and
label: BODY

text: maintaining an eldercare workforce that supports well-coordinated, high quality care
label: BODY

text: for older adults.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Christopher Laxton, CAE
label: BODY

text: Executive Director
label: HH1

text: The Honorable Bernie Sanders
label: BODY

text: United States Senate
label: BODY

text: 332 Dirksen Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, D.C. 20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Senator Sanders:
label: BODY

text: We are writing to extend our most grateful thanks to you for writing and
label: BODY

text: introducing the reauthorization of The Older Americans Act.
label: BODY

text: Donated Dental Services (DDS) is a national initiative sponsored by our
label: BODY

text: organization which is affiliated with the American Dental Association.
label: BODY

text: We provide comprehensive pro bono dental care through a network of
label: BODY

text: more than 15,000 volunteer dentists assisted by 3,200 participating
label: BODY

text: laboratories.  The program is overwhelmed by requests for assistance
label: BODY

text: from individuals who require dental care to address their medical needs
label: BODY

text: for conditions such as diabetes, cancers, cardiovascular diseases, renal
label: BODY

text: dysfunction, autoimmune diseases, and mental health challenges.  They
label: BODY

text: cannot afford the dental care and have no insurance for it.
label: BODY

text: Many more dentists are willing to participate in the DDS program and
label: BODY

text: similar charitable service initiatives.  However, they will not be
label: BODY

text: effectively engaged without the social work infrastructure such projects
label: BODY

text: require to match needy patients with available dental volunteers.  The
label: BODY

text: provision in the Reauthorization of the Older Americans Act authorizing
label: BODY

text: support for that purpose will mobilize the dental profession’s service
label: BODY

text: potential to produce significant treatment for many very vulnerable
label: BODY

text: individuals.  And because of the eligibility focus on needy elderly,
label: BODY

text: disabled, and medically compromised individuals, many of whom are
label: BODY

text: Medicare and/or Medicaid beneficiaries, this process will likely save
label: BODY

text: more money than it costs, since costly medical complications will
label: BODY

text: undoubtedly be prevented.
label: BODY

text: Again, we re extremely appreciative of all your continuing efforts to
label: BODY

text: improve services to our nation’s elderly and disabled members, and
label: BODY

text: we’re eager to assist you in any way we can in helping to bring your
label: BODY

text: efforts to fruition.
label: BODY

text: Respectfully,
label: BODY

text: Bruce Vladeck, Ph.D.
label: BODY

text: Larry Coffee, DDS
label: BODY

text: Board Member
label: BODY

text: Founder and CEO
label: BODY

text: The Honorable Bernie Sanders
label: BODY

text: Chairman
label: BODY

text: Primary Health and Aging Subcommittee
label: BODY

text: SD- 648 Dirksen Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC 20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders:
label: BODY

text: On behalf of our 156,000 members, we thank you for including important oral health
label: BODY

text: provisions in 2013 the Older Americans Act (OAA) reauthorization.  We believe that these
label: BODY

text: additions are important for increasing access to needed oral health care for senior citizens.
label: BODY

text: Sec. 425 in the bill provides for a grant program that will support national dental programs to
label: BODY

text: coordinate medically recommended dental care for low income individuals. The dental care
label: BODY

text: will be provided by volunteer dentists at no cost to patients who have medical conditions –
label: BODY

text: like diabetes, cancer, autoimmune disease, kidney disease or need heart or joint
label: BODY

text: replacements or transplants.
label: BODY

text: This legislation is needed because Medicare, which does not cover routine dental services,
label: BODY

text: will not pay for the coordination of medically recommended dental care, thereby preventing
label: BODY

text: many underserved patients from getting needed care or compromising an existing chronic
label: BODY

text: condition.
label: BODY

text: This program will reduce Medicare and Medicaid costs. For example, kidney dialysis
label: BODY

text: patients need to be able to consume enough protein to stabilize their condition. If a patient
label: BODY

text: cannot eat properly, physicians have to insert a feeding tube. A 2001 study reported that the
label: BODY

text: estimated one year cost of feeding a patient through a tube is $31,832. Under this bill, a
label: BODY

text: patient in this condition would receive free oral health services from a volunteer dentist and
label: BODY

text: avoid the need of a feeding tube.
label: BODY

text: It has been estimated that the $2 million grant investment authorized in this bill will return
label: BODY

text: roughly $13 million in medically-necessary, pro bono dental treatment and will help 5,000
label: BODY

text: Medicare and/or Medicaid beneficiaries.
label: BODY

text: We are also pleased that you have included dental expenses in Sec. 209 of the bill, which
label: BODY

text: requires the Secretary of Labor to revise the Experimental Price Index for the Elderly
label: BODY

text: commonly referred to as the CPI-E.  Adults increasingly are keeping their teeth well into old
label: BODY

text: age, placing increasing demands for services on the dental profession as well as incurring
label: BODY

text: more expense as consumers. Dental care is paid for much differently than most medical
label: BODY

text: care; therefore indexing dental expenditures will be helpful in understanding the impact of
label: BODY

text: these expenses on the elderly.  We anticipate that the greater number of elderly individuals
label: BODY

text: requiring dental care will change the way dentistry is practiced in the future. Including dental
label: BODY

text: Page 2
label: BODY

text: expenses in the CPI-E will help the dental profession better understand the impact of those
label: BODY

text: expenditures.
label: BODY

text: Thank you again for including these oral health provisions in the Older American Act
label: BODY

text: reauthorization.  This is the first time in the history of the OAA that oral health care has been
label: BODY

text: included.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Robert A. Faiella, D.M.D., M.M.Sc.
label: BODY

text: President
label: HH1

text: Kathleen T. O’Loughlin, D.M.D., M.P.H.
label: BODY

text: Executive Director
label: HH1

text: The Honorable Bernie Sanders
label: BODY

text: Chair, Subcommittee on Primary Health and Aging
label: BODY

text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions
label: BODY

text: 428 Senate Dirksen Office Building
label: BODY

text: Washington, DC  20510
label: BODY

text: Dear Senator Sanders:
label: BODY

text: On behalf of The Arc of the United States, I wish to express my sincere appreciation for your
label: BODY

text: Older Americans Act reauthorization bill.   This legislation offers significant improvements for
label: BODY

text: our nation’s family caregivers who provide the vast majority of long term services and
label: BODY

text: supports.
label: BODY

text: For more than 60 years, The Arc has worked to ensure that people with intellectual and
label: BODY

text: developmental disabilities have the supports and services they need to live as independently
label: BODY

text: and productively as possible.  Through our network of over 700 state and local chapters and
label: BODY

text: 140,000 members, we have helped to create basic protections and opportunities for the more
label: BODY

text: than 7 million people with intellectual and developmental disabilities in the U.S.
label: BODY

text: More than 65 million Americans provide care for a loved one who has a disability, is
label: BODY

text: chronically ill, or is elderly and spend an average of 20 hours per week providing care.  For
label: BODY

text: caregivers of people with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) the levels of
label: BODY

text: responsibility are not only greater, but frequently lifelong.
label: BODY

text: There are approximately 2.9 million family caregivers of persons with I/DD in the U.S.
label: BODY

text: According to The Arc’s Family and Individual Needs for Disability Supports (FINDS) survey,
label: BODY

text: most of these family caregivers provide more than 40 hours of care per week (including 40%
label: BODY

text: who provide more than 80 hours of care per week). As our society continues to depend on the
label: BODY

text: active engagement of family caregivers for the support of individuals with I/DD, it is essential
label: BODY

text: to meet the needs of those caregivers to continue providing care in the community instead of
label: BODY

text: more costly and unwanted institutions.
label: BODY

text: Family caregivers of people with I/DD urgently need the services provided by the National
label: BODY

text: Family Caregiver Support program (NFCSP) created by the Older Americans Act.  Your
label: BODY

text: legislation would finally make the NFCSP available to the majority of them who have been
label: BODY

text: excluded from the program – caregivers of persons with I/DD who are age 18 to 59.  As a
label: BODY

text: result, many more families will be able to access essential respite, counseling, training,
label: BODY

text: support group, and other services that help them to keep their loved ones at home.
label: BODY

text: In addition, the legislation would greatly help the growing number of aging caregivers to help
label: BODY

text: plan for the future of their adult children with disabilities. Over 75% of adults with lifelong
label: BODY

text: disabilities live at home with family caregivers and more than a quarter live with aging
label: BODY

text: caregivers over 60 years of age.   By expanding the role of Aging and Disability Resource
label: BODY

text: Centers (ADRCs) to begin providing future planning services, many aging caregivers will be
label: BODY

text: able to achieve the peace of mind that they deserve.   Planning for the future when aging
label: BODY

text: caregivers can no longer provide care involves specific legal and financial considerations –
label: BODY

text: such as special needs trusts, guardianship, and less restrictive protections – as well as future
label: BODY

text: residential and lifestyle preferences.  Access to these planning services will reduce the
label: BODY

text: likelihood of inappropriate residential placements, loss of intended inheritance, and limited
label: BODY

text: access to needed services for their adult children with disabilities.
label: BODY

text: Helping family caregivers to continue providing long-term services and supports is a matter of
label: BODY

text: ethical and fiscal responsibility.  We look forward to working with you on the reauthorization
label: BODY

text: of the Older Americans Act that will improve services for our nation’s caregivers.
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Annie Acosta
label: BODY

text: Policy Advocate
label: BODY

text: The Arc of the United States
label: BODY

text: Dear Chairman Sanders:
label: BODY

text: The American Geriatrics Society (AGS) supports the Older Americans Act Amendments of 2013. AGS is a national
label: BODY

text: non‐profit organization comprised of over 6,000 health professionals, including physicians, nurses, researchers,
label: BODY

text: medical educators, pharmacists, physician assistants, social workers, health care administrators, and others who
label: BODY

text: specialize in geriatrics. We are the nation's largest multi‐disciplinary health professional organization dedicated to
label: BODY

text: improving the health, independence and quality of life of older people through initiatives in clinical practice,
label: BODY

text: research and professional and public education.
label: BODY

text: We very much appreciate your efforts to move forward with reauthorization of the Older Americans Act (OAA) in
label: BODY

text: the 113th Congress.  Reauthorization of the OAA provides an important opportunity to modernize the aging
label: BODY

text: services network and its programs in order to build a health professional workforce with the skills and training to
label: BODY

text: meet the health and long‐term care services and supports (LTSS) needs of older adults.  As you know, our nation
label: BODY

text: already faces a severe and growing shortage of healthcare professionals with the training and skills to meet the
label: BODY

text: unique health care needs of older adults.
label: BODY

text: We are pleased to see provisions in the Older Americans Act Amendments of 2013 to address workforce
label: BODY

text: shortages and support family caregivers.  Several provisions in your legislation contribute to these important
label: BODY

text: goals, including requiring the Administration on Aging to work with other federal agencies to identify and address
label: BODY

text: workforce shortages in the field of aging.  The bill also tests new innovative models of person and family‐centered
label: BODY

text: care that encourage well‐coordinated, interdisciplinary team care.  Additional components provide grants to
label: BODY

text: states to conduct assessments of family or informal caregiver needs as well as the testing of models that provide
label: BODY

text: direct care workers with further training for new roles.
label: BODY

text: Chairman Sanders, AGS appreciates your leadership on this important legislation and looks forward to continued
label: BODY

text: engagement in the OAA reauthorization process.  Should you have any additional questions, please contact
label: BODY

text: Alanna Goldstein, Assistant Director of Public Affairs and Advocacy, at agoldstein@americangeriatrics.org or
label: BODY

text: Sincerely,
label: BODY

text: Cathy Alessi, MD, AGSF
label: HH1

text: Jennie Chin Hansen, RN, MS, FAAN
label: BODY
